title: What does the shrinking gap between hindu and muslim birthrate tells us?
selftext:
This has been a long running conspiracy theory and the main agenda of hindu nationalist that Hindus are in danger of a demographic take over by increasing muslim population.

A quick look at the fertility and birth rate data of different religions tells a different story.

Both Hindu and [Muslim](https://scroll.in/latest/1023559/muslims-fertility-rate-sees-sharpest-decline-over-two-decades-shows-health-ministry-survey) birth rates are [declining](https://www.reuters.com/world/india/indias-birth-control-measures-resonate-among-its-muslims-priests-play-role-2023-04-12/) almost at the same rate. Only [Jain](https://www.statista.com/chart/29365/birth-rates-india/) birth rate is increasing.



The gap between hindu and muslim birthrate is also [shrinking](https://www.livemint.com/news/india/what-a-narrowing-hindu-muslim-fertility-gap-tells-us/1550686404387.html).

Which means that in the near future muslim birthrate is going to match and then fall below hindu birthrate and at that point muslim population will start [declining ](https://indianexpress.com/article/india/fertility-falling-in-all-communities-steepest-decline-among-muslims-nfhs-data-7906994/).

Which is not very surprising considering muslims, just like any other community are facing the same [economic stressors](https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2021/11/25/india-birth-rate-replacement-population/) like increasing inflation and higher cost of living which is making it harder to raise children. 

Better access and awareness to [contraception](https://www.reuters.com/world/india/indias-birth-control-measures-resonate-among-its-muslims-priests-play-role-2023-04-12) is also playing a role.

You're under some misplaced notion that AI will lead to widespread unemployment in the future. This is not at all what most economists think. AI replaces tasks, not jobs. It makes jobs productive which generates more capital and jobs. Take it from MIT labor economist David Autor, the foremost expert in this field

https://www.aeaweb.org/articles?id=10.1257/jep.29.3.3

>In this paper, I begin by identifying the reasons that automation has not wiped out a majority of jobs over the decades and centuries. Automation does indeed substitute for labor—as it is typically intended to do. However, automation also complements labor, raises output in ways that leads to higher demand for labor, and interacts with adjustments in labor supply. Journalists and even expert commentators tend to overstate the extent of machine substitution for human labor and ignore the strong complementarities between automation and labor that increase productivity, raise earnings, and augment demand for labor. Changes in technology do alter the types of jobs available and what those jobs pay. In the last few decades, one noticeable change has been a "polarization" of the labor market, in which wage gains went disproportionately to those at the top and at the bottom of the income and skill distribution, not to those in the middle; however, I also argue, this polarization is unlikely to continue very far into future. The final section of this paper reflects on how recent and future advances in artificial intelligence and robotics should shape our thinking about the likely trajectory of occupational change and employment growth. I argue that the interplay between machine and human comparative advantage allows computers to substitute for workers in performing routine, codifiable tasks while amplifying the comparative advantage of workers in supplying problem-solving skills, adaptability, and creativity.

>and rely on technology that consume little energy instead of making babies that will starve. 

This is utopianism. This is not even happening in Europe where technological levels are much higher than India. Indian growth happens though catch up, not through tech innovations.
